explanation:
To determine whether OS_close can call itself (directly or indirectly) we must not only consider its direct callees but also the callees of those functions (and the UT stub helpers) to see if any call chain can reach OS_close. The reasons: 
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: direct callee of OS_close; any calls it makes could lead back to OS_close.
- OS_GenericClose_Impl: direct callee; may call other helpers that could recurse.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: direct callee; its callees might call back to OS_close.
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: direct callees (test harness stubs). These helpers can invoke further UT framework functions or user handlers that could indirectly call OS_close, so they must be examined.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById — include to check for any path back to OS_close.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: callee of OS_GenericClose_Impl — include to trace further calls.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish, OS_NotifyEvent: callees of OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete — include to trace further calls.
- UT_GetStubEntry, UT_ClearStubEntry, UtAssert_Abort, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl, UtAssert_GetContext: callees of the UT_* helpers — include to determine whether the UT framework or assert/handler helpers can route control back to OS_close.

With these symbols available the next analysis agent can expand call chains starting at OS_close through all reachable functions shown in the static graph and determine if any path returns to OS_close (i.e., direct or indirect recursion).
